ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a general understanding of various philosophers of education and their views on the purpose of education.
Course offers a much more transparent view of educational systems and shortcomings throughout history

I learned how to talk and write about a range of issues in education today (through the eyes of philosophers). This course was incredibly relevant to today, and it made the skills I learned all the more useful.

I learned a lot about educational policies. There was definitely a big emphasis on the political realm of things, which I felt like wasn't in the description of the class but was reasonably interesting. I got to read a variety of philosophers and I feel more prepared to discuss broad educational systems and feel more prepared to be an informed voter in this arena.

The more classes I take at Yale, the more I learn to appreciate nuance in discussion of important topics. This class was no different, and I was able to appreciate the different ideas we discussed while being taught how to think rather than what to believe.

I learned a lot in this course both in terms of vocabulary  and insight into a really good syllabus of reading material, but also improved my ability to discuss. I thing we talked about a lot of participatory readiness, and this class helps give you that. The books we read were awesome. Du Bois' "The Soul's of Black Folk" is unforgettable and I really enjoyed reading Carter G. Woodson's kind of attack against it. That was definitely my favorite part of the syllabus. I loved reading about ideas, thinking about how they were relevant today, and then seeing how other thinkers disagreed. It felt like we were always understanding more.
we learned about education policy and philosophy!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths-- interesting reading list, Prof. Stanley is great and engaging. Weaknesses-- some lack of communication on due dates/what readings are expected each week, poor and disengaged TA made for weak discussion section

Strengths: the content of the course. The content of the course is truly fascinating and the readings we did are very interesting for anyone remotely interested in education and its purpose.

Weakness: Oftentimes lectures felt very disorganized and did not cover the material we were assigned to read in its entirety so we kept falling behind as the semester went along. Slides would have been VERY useful. We spent a lot of lectures that were just Stanley scrolling through a PDF of the readings and providing commentary (that was sometimes useful but often not). I think communication surrounding logistics could be vastly improved. Oftentimes it was unclear when things were due or what we were actually assigned to read for the week (again, because we constantly kept falling behind, the reading amount kept changing throughout the semester).

This is a very enjoyable course, but it's helpful to know what you're getting into. 

The course name is a bit misleading; it's much more of a political science course than a philosophy course. The presentation of information is not particularly discursive -- it's offered more as a historical record of truth than an open debate. Which, considering the content of the class, is actually very fair; the overall takeaway from the class is that the information presented has historically been omitted from educational curricula, and is now finally being its fair worth. None of this is criticism of the class, just understand if you're considering taking it that the format is less debate-based and more historical.

That said, in that context, it is extremely valuable, useful, and enjoyable. The information is important and the readings are engaging without being overwhelming. I would recommend the class to everyone interested.

This course covered a range of very interesting material, and the professor was insanely intelligent. The only thing I'd add that might improve this course would be a slightly less reading-heavy workload.

Strengths: interesting material, manageable workload and assignments, not too many essays, participation really necessary in the small section. Weaknesses: Professor Stanley is definitely a little disorganized, which some people might be fine with but which also may frustrate some people. The op-ed assignment, which could be turned in at any point in the semester, wasn't really introduced until quite late in the semester. Assignments are sometimes unclear or not posted on time. Professor Stanley also sometimes cold calls.
I really enjoyed the readings and lectures. Section was a free discussion, which made for an exciting time.
The strength is in the syllabus and also Professor Stanley's personality. He's a goofy dude, and it made classes engaging.
The readings of this course are phenomenal, but its impossible to read 4 books in the final 4 weeks. We would learn much more if the readings were shorter at the end of the term.

Strengths: fascinating material and discussions. Weaknesses: the assignments were unorganized in terms of deadlines etc. We also only had grade back by the time classes ended (so it was difficult to track progress).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish there was a discussion board of some type, so that not all participation was dependent on class time, because the class was so big and was mainly lecture with very little time for discussion. The small discussion section worked very well though, I thought.
The lectures were about the right length to keep me engaged, and the topics were interesting. There is nothing that I would suggest to change that can be changed given the circumstances.
The discussion sections I was a part of was amazing!
The live lectures and discussion sections allowed for engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are interested in the topic. Be aware that content matter is very political philosophy heavy (although Professor Stanley explains why this is justified!). Make sure you get a good discussion section also

Not really. It was too disorganized to get anything meaningful out of it in my opinion. Most of what I got out of it came entirely from doing the readings rather than learning through lecture or discussion section.

I would recommend this course to anyone passionate about education, issues in our government/society today, or philosophy in general. Professor Stanley is fun and smart and makes the course very enjoyable.

If you are prepared to deal with a rather disorganized class and are interested in the topic, then yes. It is definitely more about educational policy than classroom methods, which I didn't realize beforehand. Come to class with a thick skin, and you will be fine. If you want to contact Professor Stanley, go to office hours rather than email. If you are truly interested in philosophy itself or education itself, this may not be the class for you, but if you want to learn about U.S. education systems and curriculum, this will be a good class for you.
I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in or passionate about education and philosophy.

I would definitely recommend this course to another person. I liked that this class didn't feel like too much of a philosophy class. It was really centered on education, and I think that made discussions less annoying (sorry philosophy classes). Readings were amazing. My mom even went to the library and got Soul's of Black Folk by Du Bois after I talked about it so much.
Yes! If you want to learn more about different systems of education and their political ramifications (especially Yale's), this is a great course.
I would recommend this course to anyone with a background in EDST and/or philosophy, but I dont think its a great starting course, given the number of readings.
Yes, great intro to relevant debates on education policy etc.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture with additional live virtual discussion section
No other modes of learning.
Additional 50 minute discussion section once per week
We also had section once a week, and lectures were recorded. The lectures were run more like seminars than lectures (in a good way).
The course was theoretically a virtual seminar, but functioned more like a lecture.
We had discussion sections once a week and readings.
Virtual lecture + discussion section
live virtual lectures and live virtual discussion sections
